review_title: A campy action movie in VR.
one_reviews_text:
Defector is quite a mixed experience. With some fun setpiece moments and generally fun arcade gampleay its easy to have a good time while playing, but a decrease in level quality after the first few and a general lack of content (about 3-4 hours) bring the experience down.

The first, second and third levels are really fun with some insane action setpieces and a fun variety of gameplay, they do a good job of making you fell like you're in a mission impossible movie, but this quality is not held up through the later levels. After that the levels arent great, the somewhat entertaining story jumps the shark and the gamplay devolves into some pretty terrible stealth and some overlong and boring shooting galleries.

There's only 5 levels in the game, meaning almost half of them kinda suck. Though there is only 5 levels, 4 of them have "branching points". These are mid-mission choices you can make, deciding between two completely different setpiece moments within one level, this adds some cool replayability to the levels. With the exception of one all of both coices in each level are equally fun.

The shooting is simple but fun amd feels like an arcade on rails shooter at times but in the best possible way. Theres some hand to hand combat sequences which  were always very fun and some interesting talking/dialogue scenes where you have to stay undercover or get information. Though the dialogue scenes do become tedious and boring on repeat playthroughs, they are fun the first time.

in summary the pros and cons are...
Pros:
+fun shooting
+great setpiece moments and branching gameplay
+action movie feeling
+fun conversations (the first time)
+great hand to hand combat sections
+great variety of gameplay in the first 3 levels
Cons:
-not much content
-levels degrade in quality
-repetitive gameplay in later levels

Overall, defector is a short but fun game with some glaring issues. Buy it on sale if it looks interesting, i bought it at full price and got my moneys worth.

It has moments where you realize how great and serious it could have been. In the end, it's a glorified arcade tech demo. The set pieces are well done, but it's how you play them in the end that matters. If you just stand there and look for targets, the whole game is a rail shooter. If you actually engage and half pretend you're Bond or Atomic Blonde or (gulp) Ethan Hunt, then it gets an extra star. Siding by and shooting at black ops while people freak out never gets old. My big gripe is hate, hate, hate bad save spots. And when matched with those annoying droid security alert things, it just makes a headache a migraine. That said, it's a blast in small doses. I feel a port to Quest would give it another star as it begs to be played more freely. I'm still waiting for the AAA spy Bond VR.

Look, there are parts of this game I enjoy. When I get that genuine feeling of espionage, holding some out the window of a building try to get information out of them. Sneaking through a spy plane's security and then getting to jump out of it. That stuff is fun.

The rest of this game isn't. The first disappointment I had - one that lasted through the game - was how many object I couldn't interact with. I get that it could be an oversight to make the soap dispenser work, or the sink actually have flowing water, but I can only remember one object I could interact with in the opening of the game; an object that was copied and pasted multiple times in the same room.

A small complaint, I guess, but being able to interact with the world is one of the selling points of VR. Other than that, some missions are downright awful, some are mediocre, and some are entertaining. Most fall into the mediocre category.

Checkpoints are placed far too far apart and make you recomplete obnoxious sections of the level, there are boring dialogue sequences inbetween actual gameplay (nevermind how nonsensical and vague the plotline is), and one particular section of the game made me feel silly, which is surprisingly difficult to achieve in VR. --Light Spoiler-- The level has you short circuit a giant death robot and yank its arm off to use as a gun. It's incredibly hard to aim and boring to fire, considering the actual fire-arms (mind the pun) you can pick up after killing enemies. It was stupid.

If you really, really like the idea of an espionage spy game, buy it on sale. Otherwise, there are a lot of other great games for you to get.

This game looked fun in reviews and trailers, but the gameplay I experienced fell far below my expectations. I beat it in 3 hours, and was thoroughly disappointed with how little replay value there was. The last few missions of the game were so far from the rest of the game that it didn't even feel like the same game. Games like Robo Recall and Super Hot have a similar price tag but I have played for much longer and had a much more enjoyable experience. This is by far the most disappointing purchase I have made on the VR platform.

Even while playing this game I was already bracing myself for the "it's too short" whining.  It's twenty dollars.  TWENTY.  If the game was twice as long it would be worth it for three times the price.  It's a fantastic thrill ride that I already can't wait to play again.  Just a couple things to consider: while it has an option for teleporting, some moments may be too intense for the really motion sensitive out there.  Another: the penultimate mission IS disappointing.  When there's only five missions having one without any branching options that drops you right in after the tension escalation has occurred feels short-changing.  They're denying the gamer much needed storytelling in an already fairly short experience.  That said, everything else is flawlessly executed.  They've taken us off the rails (one of my complaints with Wilson's Heart) and brought they're perfectly executed physical interaction with them.  I wish every VR game let me interact with objects as well as Twisted Pixel games do.  Nice job!  Totally worth the wait!

review_title: THIS IS LANDMARK IN VIDEO GAME HISTORY
one_reviews_text:
This is the first actual full game that I have played in vr. I have oculus, gear and psvr.  Every game that I have played until this point has been one dimesional and repetitve. Don't get me wrong, I have enjoyed a lot of these games. The developers have been creative with a lot of titles. Robo recall for instance. Super fun but its not a splinter cell, dying light, zero dawn or far cry.

Defector has layers and variety. You fist fight, drive (a little), sneak, shoot, hack, chase a villian through city streets and more. The dialogue gets cheesy but you won't mind. I have to be honest,  if this were a non vr game, I would not give it a good review. I am giving it a good review because this is the first VIRTUAL REALITY game that I have ever played that even attemps to give the depth and variety that you get in a good non vr game like the games I mentioned before. AND because its more than just an attempt, I was entertained. If this is an indicator of where vr is going, I am very exited. I TOTALLy recommend purchasing this game.

I know how challenging this game must have been for the developers. I want them to keep trying. We need to support this game so they will keep making vr games like this. Also the game IS WORTH PLAYING. the mechanics of the game are good everything flows well. The graphics are what they should be. The stroryline...  IT ACTUALLY HAS A STORYLINE. This is my first VR game with an actual storyline not just a backstory. It is not the best or worst storyline, you act out the story through the game. I think that was pretty smart of the developers to do it that way.  VR games or very cumbersome from a computing standpoint that is why we see a lot of shallow games.  The developers used their limited resources ingeniously when they made this game.

This one one helluva first try at making a full game in VR.
GOOD JOB GUYS

Seeing the trailer video from Free Fall... really made me excited about this game. Seriously I was looking every othe day when this would released. And when finally did and I completed the first level, and was REALLY satisfied. All the action, the conversation sequences and first and foremost, the fist fight.

Well of course, everything is kept very simple. You cannot really make a mistake in the conversations. The puzzles are super simple. But just by doing all of them, the game can really give you a feeling that you are a master spy. This is what this game was about for me... the experience in the moment regardless of you would replay this game. 

It is true the arc of tension has a huge valley at around the middle of the game. I found the robot levels boring myself. But acutally it is better to have a high at the beginning and a high at the end. Having said that, I did not really like the branch I chose in the end, but the surpising final scene still give it a nice finish.

I wonder how many of the users checked out the extra content. Even if it is not hours more, it is still way more than in other games. Just checking out the 3d models, or the art concepts and the hilarious test levels.

The bottom line is, in spite of the imperfactions this game offered some really unique moments of experience that I will never forget. Many other VR games I played... I cannot even remember just one thing..

review_title: Best Single Player since Lone Echo.
one_reviews_text: The title of this review says it all. I know there are other good shooters out there thats been around for awhile now. But this game was my first true fps VR experience. I held off on others until i seen something that truly caught my eye. And this game did just that. I love how you can litterally hold your gun out around the corner of a wall and fire off at your enemies. The only two small cons i see in this game is a small tracking issue i get when holding an assault rifle with both touch controllers but that could be an isolated issue for me since i only have two sensors setup for "Front Facing" type gameplay. The second being when you come across ammo crates make sure to NOT drop the ammo clips you want to keep and move on with, they will disappear instantly, So be careful of that. This game looks great graphically and comes extremely close to as polished as Lone Echo was in the beginning. Pick this one up. If not now, most certainly when they finally have it one sale!

This game is absolutely amazing! I am only through 3 missions and it has blown my mind. Looks great, feels outstanding and action packed. I'm mostly a multiplayer VR guy so I was hesitant, especially after dropping $40 on Blood and Truth. This game is what Blood and Truth wanted to be. Totally renewed my faith in an action story single player game. Each mission is unique and adds new mechanics so nothing ever feels stale. Don't eat for the day save your $20 and drop it on this game right now.

When I origianlly saw the trailer for this game on oculus, I thought it looked amazing. However upon purchase I found the gameplay to be boring and repetitive. The story assumed you knew so many things about the characters and the world and while it didnt punish you very harshly for choosing the incorrect option, the restarting from checkpoint and having to rewatch a cutscene was annoying after a certain point. There was also no sense of urgency, I found myself taking my time in most of the missions because I had no reason or desire to do otherwise. The combat consisted of mabey 5 different weapons most of which you dont even use more than once depending on the routes you take. The only unique combat system whatsoever was the blocking and attacking during melee fights which yet again depending on your path you may only encounter around 3 of. The combat was also Incredibly easy, I found myself using only around 4 health packs the entire game and one of the four was on accident. I probably only died 12 times max out of the 6-7 levels and most of the deaths were just from being bored during combat and not immediately killing enemies. The segment with the enemy drones on the final mission was incredibly easy and you could almost just walk straight through certain sections without dying or even getting hit for that matter. Your 'choices' only effect the outcome of the game in mabey 1-3 different points which seems like whatever attempt there was at making a choice story driven game was just not given any significant and detailed thought. The instructions were unclear in many segments and I found myself questioning what to do in many segments with the objectives tab providing no assistance.

Tired of the wave based shooters? Multiplayer FPS? Want to take a break from your racing sims or the one hour walking simulators? Dont get me wrong, I love all VR games/experiences, but we need Defector. We need good story based single player games so we can eventually get to the Tomb Raiders and The last of us VR type games. Defector is a solid well done action spy story with two different endings. A 5 star VR game worth playing. Very enjoyable

I'm still going to give this game five stars because it delivers what it promises, but for Pete’s sake, give us movement OPTIONS!  
At first when I visited the options I thought great, the ability to not move in head direction is available, fantastic, I can look in one direction and move forward by the stick in the direction of the controller; NOPE!  If you choose not to use head direction and turn in real life (like we all do that are used to 360 playspace), when you press forward on the left stick it always takes your initial ‘forward position’ as its direction, so you move like a crab in that direction no matter the orientation of your controller.  This is difficult to describe, but impossible to use.  Therefore you end up needing to use head direction as direction of travel and strafe like you would with KB&M if you want to look around while walking.  This is VR for goodness sake, we have head tracking!!!  There are now 3 plains of movement we can use; 1) Forward/Back/Strafe [left stick] 2) Turn Left/Right [right stick] 3) LOOK (head).  Yet developers still insist on mimicking the inferior KB/M and standard Console Controller 2 plain system (i.e. sans look).  
Disappointing to say the least.

review_title: Best single player VR Experience to date
one_reviews_text:
It's good, I'm 2 missions in. The attention to detail in the world is not to be understated, this game has had a lot of love and care put into it. The art style works really well for VR, and the faces don't look uncanny like most VR games. The conversation system is immersive, similar to something like Mass Effect. The A/B Choice of mission objectives is also nice. The graphics are some of the best I've seen in a VR game, and most of that comes down to attention to detail in art design, not raw fidelity.

Audio is spot on, hand tracking is amazing. I experience absolutely no motion sickness even in the hectic "on rails" moments. This game has definite callbacks to Goldeneye 007 on N64 with "Cheats" like "Big Head Mode" and so on. The game has a sense of humour and doesn't take itself too seriously.

I would have expected to pay the full 60AUD for this game, but it's only 25AUD. I'd consider it a must buy.

My only request so far would be to please allow hand based locomotion, not just head. This is standard for all 360 games these days and really should be included.

EDIT: I have no finished the game. The first 2 missions felt really strong, but then as the game progressed it felt even more arcadey and unpolished. 

***SPOILERS BELOW***




The final boss fight was really underwhelming, the first fighting mechanic was cool. But the moment where you stun him and then have to throw him into things, I was actually spending upwards of 2mins straight trying to throw the guy. It just wouldn't work. The game doesn't make it clear where you're supposed to throw him, or the direction of hand action required to do so. I remember the first fist fight being really intuitive and easy, but the final boss fight felt awkward and rushed. The quality, polish and attention to detail lasted the ENTIRE way through the game I would give 5 stars.

The combat parts are ok. I thought it was an odd design decision to make the best gun in the level the one they give you, and give it unlimited ammo. You can pick up other guns off of enemies, but you're limited to what's in the magazine and they're far inferior to what you're given anyway. At the beginning of the game you sit at a table with a "bad guy" in front of you. So while he was babbling around I looked at the objects on the table right in front of me. There were apples, glasses, cutlery and such stuff. Typical objects perfect to show the physics of a game. So I lifted the tablet and... oh, all the objects on it just fell throw. Okay maybe the tablet was just an illusion. So I thought lets look how he reacts when I throw some of the objects on his "wife" sitting next to us (yes every character in such a game has to be a test-dummy on demand). So I threw an apple at her head: No reaction. Not from him. Not from her. Then a knife to the head: No reaction. Then a glass to the head: It broke directly on her face! Still no reaction. Yeah she is a pro as we will learn, but WTF?
Also the most of the objects lying around you cant even grab. The environment feels static and lifeless, non-responsive. And that really kills a lot of immersion for me. review_title: A wonderful but unfinished VR game
one_reviews_text:
I want to be able to give this game 5 stars because, especially at the $20 price tag, it's one of the best VR games I've played.  It explores a lot of fun mechanics that create an immersive and interesting experience.  The polish is, for the most part, really shiny and nice.  There are, however, some aspects of the game that make it feel incomplete or stale.

Just a quick list of negatives:
1.) The ammo and gun systems feel watered down and lack feel.  When reloading and shooting, the game feels like the developers went through many iterations of mechanics, and had to rush out a simplified system to meet a deadline.  Just as an example, when you look at your available magazines there's the illusion of limited supply, but it's actually unlimited. 

2.) There's some pretty clumsy waveshooting elements to the game; which is a shame because it feels a little out of place with how tight the narrative aspects are assembled.  If the AI were smarter, the health system more complex and interesting, and the gunplay tighter then some of these moments of the game could have been really exciting.  Instead, they come off as bland and almost annoying. 

3.)  Finally, while I haven't finished the game yet, I've played enough to feel like the pacing is really jerky and uneven.  All of the loading between the narrative portion and the levels feels like a late-90s title.  It makes it difficult to appreciate a lot of the aspects of a game that the title did really well.

Now, here's a quick list of things that are really great, and leave me excited for future games similar to this title.

1.) The story-branching system is neat
2.) The NPC interations, while underdeveloped, are well-done
3.) The visuals some of the best you've seen in a VR title

As clumsy as aspects of this game may be, it's absolutely worth playing.  It's one of the best VR games available, and it will give you a taste of the future of AAA VR gaming.

The fun moments in this game are exhilarating but inconsistent. The devs put their best foot forward with the first mission, and that portion of the game shows the most polish. The few and far between gun play scenes are arcade-inspired fun. 

Too much of the rest of the game is met with poorly defined checkpoints to be reached in an ultra-linear fashion. The dialog trees don’t actually do anything because you’re only presented with one pathway forward. Navigating menus seems like a poor design choice that keeps things from feeling integrated. You can’t carry very many items, so rather than a menu system it would be far more immersive if you could store the items on your person—the only issue is that you’re a disembodied ghost save for your hands.  

My biggest issue with the game is that it forces you to play exactly how the developers intend with ZERO deviation. Given the previews, I was hoping for a more Hitmanesque creative experience of role playing, where the player can establish their own path in a spy thriller, but this is more of an on-the-tracks roller coaster that has far too many slowly climbing luls where you’re anticipating the next bit of punctuated excitement.

review_title: Fun super spy game with some flaws
one_reviews_text: Overall it feels more like a 2016 VR game than something contemporary. I’ll be honest that after the first stage the game started to feel like a bit of a slog to get through. My teenager self would’ve loved this game a lot, but the 42yo side of me felt this game had a lot of tired spy tropes, some super awkward turning controls, and a story that felt like it just wanted to setup action set pieces just for the sake of than really tell something remotely interesting. Sure that last part gets to the point, but narratively it doesn’t hardly try. Honestly the story didn’t get good until shortly before and after the credits in that Marvel kind of way.

Only through two and a half levels, and have replayed those three times already just because I wanted to do it all again right after finishing. And there are branching options which do affect the story.  Needs a beefy pc to run at max. Graphics are if not the best close to it. Gun battles are really fun.
